newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian fund managers bullish for 1997.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian fund managers bullish for 1997.

text.p: Malaysia's stock market could see hefty gains in 1997, underpinned by political stability and a moderating economy, Malaysian fund managers predict.

"There are no negative sentiments on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, there are not likely to be any major political events and the current account deficit is improving," said Nik Ezar Nik Bolia, chief executive of DCB-RHB Unit Trust Management Bhd.

Malaysia's gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 9.5 percent in 1995, raising market fears that the economy was overheating. An 18.7 billion ringgit ($7.42 billion) current account deficit in that year was also a major concern.
Since then, the government has lifted short-term interest rates and curbed spending. GDP growth, for example, is expected to moderate to a more manageable 8.2 percent for 1996.
Fund managers, including Nik Ezar, favour finance, infrastructure development and selected consumer stocks in the new year.
"The finance sector should be good in 1997. We are anticipating a 150 basis point drop in interest rates over the next 12 months," he said.
This would make consumers likely to spend more on durable goods and invest more in property and the stock market, he said.
Nik Ezar, whose DCB-RHB manages around one billion ringgit in funds, expects the benchmark Composite Index to hit the 1,300 mark by the end of the first half of 1997.
The blue chip barometer, which gained 24 percent in 1996, closed Friday at 1,231.45, up a slight 0.92 points on the day.

DCB-RHB is a unit of financial and property group Rashid Hussain Bhd, whose funds are managed by Rashid Hussain Asset Management Sdn Bhd which oversees a total of 2.7 billion ringgit, making the asset management firm one of the largest privately-owned fund managers in the country.
Other fund managers are even more bullish, predicting the index will break its previous record of 1,332.04 set on January 5, 1994.
"By December (1997) 1,350 to 1,400 on the Composite Index is not unreasonable," said Arnold Lim, general manager of HLG Asset Management, a unit of Malaysia's Hong Leong Group.

Lim expects the rally to be mainly fuelled by demand for infrastructure-related stocks. "There will be a rush to complete many infrastructure projects before the 1998 Commonwealth Games (to be held in Kuala Lumpur)," he said.
Nik Ezar said he anticipates more mergers and acquisitions within the banking industry, something the government has been encouraging to make Malaysian banks more competitive.
In the second half of 1996, several banks merged or were acquired by other financial institutions. Several more banks are rumoured to be considering such tie-ups.
The building supplies and construction industry is also likely to benefit from continued spending on basic infrastructure development within the country, said Nik Ezar.
Construction companies like Sungei Way Bhd, and Gamuda Bhd are among his favourites, he said.

Telecommunications stocks, particularly Technology Resources Industries Bhd (TRI) are also likely to be watched closely, he said. "If it falls to four ringgit, it's a 'buy'," he added, referring to Technology Resources.
The influence of foreign funds on the Malaysian market has always been significant due to its relatively small market capitalisation.

"Some foreign funds are re-rating us. More European and U.S. funds are now looking at Malaysia differently, and between 1997 and 1998 there should be stronger interest here," said Pearlene Cheong, research manager of K.L. Mutual Fund.
($1 = 2.52 ringgit)
